reviews.review_text: Beside the Torchlight franchise, Titan Quest and the free Path of Exile NeocoreGames' Van Helsing represents another alternative for those finding the latest Diablo entry a bit too casual. What's more is that while Van Helsing is shorter than aforementioned hack 'n' slash games it still offers a decent story and a lot of content. Due to the additional game modes (scenario and neverending story) it has a high replayability value, as well.  The game follows a quest of Van Helsing and his companion, the ghost Katharina, who try to get to Borgovia to stop a mad scientist. Along the way you encounter dozens of different enemies throughout numerous different environments. Some of these locales look stunningly beautiful: you traverse through a muddy forest fighting hideous monsters and evil spirits and also join the resistance in a town to fight the soldier-machines. These machines add the steampunk part of the game - with all the traps and contraptions you find they make the game even more diverse.  One of the things I liked about Van Helsing was its atmosphere. Sound effects and the score are excellent and I liked the sarcastic conversations between Helsing and Katharina. One-liners are common from them as well as from enemies and there are numerous references to other video games and films throughout the game. In order to find all of them it's worth hovering the cursor over all objects in every environment - Van Helsing might collect a quest item or just make a funny comment.  There are many sidemissions, of course, as it is common in this genre and there's even one that takes you throughout the game. You just need to carefully look everywhere and open all chests, containers, destroy all barrels and boxes as you might find the next piece of the puzzle. It's worth mentioning, though, that not all items are related to a quest, still, they will be part of the corresponding tab in your inventory.  Normally, Van Helsing wields two swords and two pistols. You can decide which way to go from there in terms of customisation. Beside these two tabs there is also one called Tricks (active spells) and Auras (passive skills). Every level-up grants you ability points (the good-old attributes we are talking about here), skill points and occasionally reputation points, but the latter is not related to quest but more to the annihilation of strong beasts. Your reputation can then yields you perks - the list is gradually increasing and you can pick more and more of them along the way.  Katharina, the ghost companion is a bit similar to the pet we have in Torchlight. She can do the shopping on behalf of us and can also pick up loot by category. Her behaviour is completely modifiable. Of course, she has many skills and also attributes - her skills either make her stronger or support Van Helsing in combat.   While there are no other companions in the game the abovementioned customisation I described for Van Helsing is the Hunter class only. With the added DLCs you can play as a Thaumaturge or Arcane Mechanic. I hear they are pretty fun and diverse, too, so this is all the more in favour of the longevity of this game.  Van Helsing is pretty cool game considering it is a relatively low-budget hack 'n' slash. It is filled with content and there's high replayability due to the 3 different classes, more difficulty levels, hardcore mode, online cooperative mode in the game. I look forward to playing with its sequel. In the meantime, if you are the fan of the genre Van Helsing should be in your library. Word of advice: buckle up as the game can be pretty challenging even on normal difficulty setting!

This game is as its name implies: 'INCREDIBLE'!  I have played Diablo, Diablo 2, Torchlight, Torchlight 2, and not one of them was as pure fun as this.  The main characters, Van Helsing and Katharina are what makes the game great. They're incredibly funny to listen to. Great dialogue, with very nice voiceovers which seem almost impossibly good for such a small game. The references to other games, books and movies are great and fit the tone, which is always one of (mostly) lighthearted fun. The game is set in a sort of dark steampunk/clockwork setting, but it always aims to amuse and not to drag you down. It doesn't take itself too seriously and that is rare in games like this.  It is a solid ARPG, and the mechanics are simple and still have depth and it's really fun and rewarding trying out different approaches. You can play your Van Helsing as a gun-toting Monsterhunter or as a sword-fighting Slayer. You can even play him as a Mage. Each class plays very different and you can also adjust your companion similarly, which is a great idea.  As I said, I got more fun out of this than Torchlight 2, for example (the story here and the graphics fit my tastes better), so it is a definitve must buy for any ARPG fan, especially if it's on sale.

There are also other numerous bugs (now with fixes via the /FixQuest command) - and MP hasn't worked for many (perhaps patched today as well) and warning of data loss for MP characters. For some, having your game not progress unexpectedly, requiring you to search the web for solutions, isn't enjoyable or expected from Steam games.  Perhaps now, the game is bug free. Perhaps not. A great ARPG. Does everything we want from an ARPG title, and a bit more. Does have some flaw, but not a deal breaker. The first series of a trilogy. Review based on GOTY version as the based version might have other flaws as mentioned by other review.   Pro     Memorable companion. The ghost companion makes me feel like I'm not just going out to kill monster randomly. I’m out for an adventure. She’s a playful character and does make all those little things interesting by her quirky remarks.    Quest system. The main quest system doesn’t differ much from any other ARPG, but the side quest is where it gets interesting. The game doesn’t use the standard exclamation-mark-quest-here for all quest. The quest might be out there hidden in the nearby area by interactable items. Once you get the item, read what the item tells you and look for any related items in the surrounding area.    Tower defence mini game. The game manages to incorporate a tower defence game without slipping away from its main genre. You can’t fully rely on the traps provided thus you should deploy the trap tactically and let you yourself be the main defence. Unfortunately, there are not much chance to play this mini game and only playable depending on the storyline.    The skill systems are well made. You have lots of build choice you can make. With the skill refund, you can change your playstyle midgame. The build might not be well balanced, but it might be just me, not good at creating a build.   Con     Artificial difficulty. As other mention, the game uses artificial difficulty by employing a sheer number of enemies. I’m not saying the enemies design are bad, but you always need to fight with a sheer number of them, and by that I mean, a buttload of them up to the point that you can’t move due to being surrounded by them. It is not undefeatable though.    Some skills are pure useless. The skill itself aren’t bad, but due to the artificial difficulty, some skills, especially single target skills are worthless. You’ll only use AOE skills or you won’t make it to kill each of the enemies one by one.    The game feels pretty short. Granted that this is only the first part of a trilogy, but it does feels a bit short. Nevertheless, it makes you want to continue with the second instalment. Probably it’s not really a con point.     Some bug and glitches can still be seen. For example, the Mana per second for Ray of Destruction skill are listed as Skill.Common.ManaCostPerSecond.

I want to like this game. The writing is decent and enjoyable, the ambiance is interesting, and it has a pet system similar to Torchlight, but with more customization and leveling options.  However, ultimately, in my experience, it devolves into a tedius grind at higher levels, where virtually every fight wound up being 'aggro group of enemies, kite for an unforgivably long time until all dead, run to next group of enemies', and I really can't overlook that. Maybe it would have been better if I hadn't been playing on Hard difficulty, but the lack of variation in enemy AI and length of time every enemy took to kill really wore on me.  Go download some mods for Torchlight II if you want to reinvigorate your Diablo-like experience.

A ton of fun. If you liked Titan Quest, this feels like a spiritual successor. It's not very long, guessing around 20 hours. I got it for less than $7 though, and that's a great value. I'll probably replay it at some point as well. I'd say it's easily worth the price at full price too. It feels more engaging than your typical isometric arpg, especially playing at higher difficulties. They made most of the abilities have combinations, so you're constantly doing things. Unless you're playing the game on an easier difficulty, it shouldn't be a matter of spamming a single ability over and over (which is nice compared to a majority of these style games).  The leveling system feels nice. It's usually exciting to get a new level. There's also a reputation system, where you get to choose a new strong buff after gaining enough reputation. The reputation system felt a bit slow, though. I'm nearly at the end of the game and I've gotten around 6 levels in reputation. The loot system felt on-par with other games in this genre. I got the feeling that there weren't many 'set' items, but that actually was a positive thing given the length of the game and it's focus on a single player experience. I was able to complete 2 sets in my playthrough. I usually don't like forced companions in these types of games, but I enjoyed the companion in this one. She had a lot of dialog, and actually felt helpful. She also buffs you as you level her up. There are side quests that give you unique items for the main Hunter class, but you can equip them on your companion if you're not a hunter.  Overall, I had a ton of fun with this game, and I highly recommend it if it's on a sale or even if it's not. Just keep in mind isometric arpgs are not everyone's cup of tea.  I did not try the multiplayer, so I cannot comment on that.

One of those rare instances where the zerg rush has been perfected outside of an RTS. The first in a trilogy of games, Van Helsing's Hack and Slash adventure offers some surprisingly diverse game play, witty banter, teeth grinding moments, and an overall good experience in one package.    The game allows for easy switching between ranged and melee attacks. You're ghostly companion is also useful, as well as buffs you. The game itself is well done, with a pletora of items, stats, askills, and abilities to tweak to your hearts content. It also gives you the ability to adjust your stats and skills (for a price) so you don't have to worry about making a mistake in your build. The story is also interesting, with some good humour written into it.   The game itself is a little buggy. Music tends to dissapear at times, and the melee skill habitually dissapeared, very annoying during a fight. Even on normal, enemy density is quite large in some areas, resulting in the veritable zerg rush that can quickly get you killed if your not ready for it. While it does force you to put some thoughts into tactics, it can also be quite annoying at times (waaaaaay too much zerg on the last boss).    The other potential issue, is that the other two classes, and the ability to manually level your companion, have to be acquired via dlc.    Overall however, this was an excellent and enjoyable game that is worth trying if you are into diablo-esque games (though you may want to try and pick it up on sale so you can get the all the dlc at a good price). Looking forward to playing th next two parts in the series to see how the plot will thicken.

The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is an ARPG. It's a very good, entertaining ARPG. I've had plenty of fun with the game, especially once the online was fixed and I picked up the Thaumaturge. The dialouge is surprisingly entertaining, but not all that great. The back and forth with Katarina and the hunter is especially amusing. There are a few other humorous characters (like the priest in the village), but no one really THAT memorable.  The combat is pretty standard fare for the genre, but it's not bad, or even bland. I'm not a Diablo 2 veteran or anything, so I can't really say for sure how 'done-to-death' this whole system is, but I enjoyed it.  IT'S a good game. If you like ARPGs, or want to try them, it's not a bad one to pick up. Especially if it's on sale. Like it is right now.

The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing Complete Pack is a beautiful, isometric action-rpg that provides a challenging experience which has a sense of humor, an interesting companion system, satisfying combat, very buggy controller support, and some noteworthy differences from the base version.  There's a lot of quirky referential humor in the game that I do not want to spoil here. Just make sure to explore everywhere and talk to everyone and... everything, especially in the first town. The world is not grim dark; it has a joke or two up its sleeve.  Katarina, Van Helsing's companion, is very helpful and has very interesting ways to alter her behavior to fit your play style. She will level up with you and has her own set of skills, two with the DLC. You can also choose three different states for her which include ghost (peaceful), melee, and ranged. You can alter how aggressive she is with enemies. She can also pick up different items of varying rarities automatically according to player desires. I had her pick up all the gold, ignore the white items, pick up the magic items, and fight enemies in melee form. It is a neat feature that is greatly appreciated and should be present in more games with companions/followers.  The combat requires you to pay attention and engage its systems if success interests you. The game has a combo system that alters how a skill can be used. For example, Earthquake, a spell that deals damage in a line, has three different power-ups that can be used in a combo: Brutal Stomp which adds 1.5 meters to the skill's width, Intense Shockwave which adds 30% more damage, and Scorching Fumes which burns everything hit for 10% of Van Helsing's Spellpower. You can spend skill points on the ones you want and organize them in whatever order. You stack up to three combos with the a, s, and d keys resulting in a very powerful skill waiting to be used. I went with 90% additional damage for Earthquake with a high critical chance build to great effect. I could have gone with 1.5 meters to width and 60% additional damage. Other skills have different power-ups available for experimentation. You will be working with Katarina to dispose of monsters while using tricks to change the flow of battle. I often used the one that freezes time to give myself a chance to observe the situation and line up Earthquake perfectly, especially when fighting extremely large groups.  This game will test the average player's abilities, but the systems it has in place makes it forgiving and approachable. Despite dying a good dozen or so times during my time with the game, I only had to pay a bit of gold to resurrect and continue the battle against evil. There are also special npcs in towns that can refund skill points for both the player and Katarina should you want to try a different build or made a mistake in your allocations.  Do not use a controller with this game. Playing this game with a controller resulted in a frustrating battle with the user interface. Looking at the skill power-ups wouldn't work for skills at the bottom of the page and laying down certain traps did not turn out very well. The combat experience works well enough, but the UI problems are severe enough to just stick with mouse and keyboard. The UI for mouse and keyboard results in faster interactions for everything and lets you properly look at all the information available. I spent fifteen hours with this game using the controller until I finally decided to stop torturing myself. The last four hours were blissful.  Finally, the complete pack comes with three different pieces of DLC which includes an additional skill tree for Katarina known as Blue Blood and two more classes, Thaumaturge and Arcane Mechanic. The Blue Blood tree has some really powerful abilities that drastically change Katarina's performance. She could rival me in power and I do not know what I would have done without her. Blue Blood allows for major damage, health, and defense increases. It also gives her different passive spells that she can activate based on chance or even death for one of them (big explosion). It even adds an often used Trick called Ghostly Mirage which allows for two Katarina illusions that can deal damage. The two extra classes, basically a mage and a scientist/engineer, have one main skill tree and a heavily modified Tricks tree allowing for a different experience from the Hunter who wields swords and/or pistols with some magic. If the classes do not interest you, I still heavily recommend Blue Blood unless you want an extra challenging experience.  The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is a good action-rpg that should entertain those familiar with the genre. Again, I am heavily recommending to not use a controller with this game.

Van Helsing is a good indie aRPG. I say indie, because if this had been released from a well known publisher it would have been treated as garbage and been on every 80% off sale it could find. Why do I say that? Well first let me just say that I wholly recommend this game! It's very fun and engaging. It presents a decent reward system. The graphics and sounds go along well with the pace of the action. So why call it garbage?   I didn't, I said it would have been treated as garbage had it been released from a big company. Van Helsing has bugs... Game breaking bugs wherein you can not complete main/storyline quests. Multiplayer bugs where games will just crash randomly or lag for no apparent reason or even spawn you into places where you are not supposed to reach thereby making you have to quit and return to the game. No tutorial for advanced features. Want to know how to upgrade (socket) items? So do I, go look for a youtube video, because this game honestly never tells you. The sounds, while going along well are somewhat repetative or campy. Also, the graphics, while they look well, enemies have a tendency to blend into the scene making it hard to know if you've killed everyone. It sports a strange control scheme and has no option to evade combat. If you're ranged and you get swarmed you can't run away because clicking in any direction means you're going to auto-attack. Also, if you have a controller plugged in, the game will not allow you to use a mouse and keyboard. You must exit, disconnect the controller, and restart the game.  Wooo... That was a long list of dislikes! I'm sorry, but I want you to know what you're getting into if you decide to purchase this title. Van Helsing has issues, BUT the game is fun! There is good dialogue and a story that makes sense. How many aRPG's have a story... and that makes sense!? The action is paced very well and never gets boring. There are quite a few quests to complete and I never had an issue figuring out where to go to complete them. Even though there are bugs the development team is working hard to correct them. Yes there are some instances where quests can't be completed, but until that's fixed, they've released a patch where you can bring up a console and complete the quest you're stuck on. The DLC classes provide more options. I like the Thaumaturge class. I'm very squishy, but I can take down the largest of monsters with ease.   So here's my final recommendation: If you like aRPG's and are looking for something to fill the gap between releases from big companies then I say grab this title. You will not be dissapointed. If aRPG's are not in your cup of tea, this game will not change your mind. If you are on the fence, just look over my comments about the bads and the goods. If you can live with the bads I think you'll find a lot of fun to be had here!

This is a pretty fun game to play if you're a fan of action hack n' slash RPGs like Diablo. I really didn't know what to expect when first playing, but I was pleasantly surprised. Coming from playing too much Diablo 3, I was glad that the game had more customization to your character. You are free to add points to your attributes and skill points in a skill tree.  As far as the gameplay goes, it took a little bit for the game to take off for me. First, each class has a rage bar that goes up during combat. You use part of the rage bar to activate extra effects to your attacks, like stunning enemies for 2 seconds to your electric attack. You have a primary left and right-click attack, followed by 1-4 key press 'trick' abilities, like healing. You don't level really fast, so to start getting new skills took a bit of dedication to the game. Stick with it, and you will enjoy your adventure with your ghostly companion. As far as difficulty goes, the game was nearly impossible for me on the highest difficulty. I suggest playing on the next level below that if you want a challenge that's do-able.  I do like the that game has decent voice acting, since your characters will talk a lot during your adventure. When you fight monsters, you will generally be fighting a LOT at once, which really causes you to stay on your toes. It has the same feel as Diablo, fighting champion packs and elite monsters. And of course, the loot which ranges from basic non magically items to epic/set.

Played the game on hard mode. The previous reviews pretty much summarized the good sides of this game: - Well designed world. - Some really nice background music (definitely getting game OST if there is one).  - Attractive graphics. - Highly customizable settings (could play this game on my laptop). - Some interesting references to pop culture (really liked Baggins dude!). - Good voice acting. - Decent storyline.  But all in all I would advise you to avoid this game. Here is why: - If you do not buy DLCs then there is only one character class you can 'choose' from. The character can do both melee and range attacks, however, due to horrible difficulty balance I had to specialize only on one attack type. The result is there is not a lot of variation in the action.  - Except very rare short conversations, the sidekick ghost lady is useless. She dies really fast and eats up all the health potions. I have ended up keeping her in a ghost form all the time. The result is the game would not change much if she was removed completely. - The game gives you impression of customization, but it actuallly punishes you for doint it. After mid point of the game, customization becomes really expensive and you can end up spending all the gold and still not getting what you want. - The essense system (aka gems and gem slots) is useless. Items where you can put gems are rare. If one is found then usually it does not have enough essense capacity to put useful essense. You can use an essense to increase the capacity but during my 27 hours of gameplay I had collected only 3 capacity increasing essense. Finally, there is not a lot of variation in essense types. I had collected only 20 or so different essense types during the entire game! - The fighting becomes really repetitive quite fast. There are many enemies that look different, but really just a skin deep difference. All off them can be categorized into melee enemies that charge in mass, melee enemies with hooks and ranged enemies. There is no interesting behavior from AI. More challenging enemies have simply 1) more HP and higher defense points, 2) just attack in bigger numbers, or 3) have more HP and defense and attack in higher numbers. It is not possible to use interesting tactics. Most of my gameplay consisted of repeating two things: have a short skirmish and then running away to use potion before having another short skirmish. Bullet spongy enemies just killed all the fun for me in this game. Most annoying are the enemies with hooks. It is not possible to predict or avoid hooks using your skills. The hook animation is instantaneous. The problem is, at least on higher difficulty, if you get hooked then you are basically dead. - Horrible camera angles. It is not possible to control the camera. Did I tell you about enemies with hooks? Well many times I was hooked by enemies I could not even see. I am not even talking about number of times I was shot at by enemies outside of the screen. - Bad character controls. There is no keyboard-based movement control. Mouse is used to click on a place where you want to move your character. Sounds good enough right? Well not. Combined with horrible camera angles and enemies swarming everywhere you will end up in many situation where you cannot find a free space to click on and move your character. I ended up more than dozen times dead because my character refused to move. The complexity of the surrounding world makes the situation even worse because it is not immediately obvious where you can and cannot click.  If you are looking for a good ARPG then go for Path of Exile. PoE is superior to this game in everyway. Plus, PoE is free, and there is no DLC nonsense.
